title: 112_hr3733
content: The Act titled "Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011" allows for principal reduction of mortgages owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The Act "Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011" mandates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce interest rates on qualified mortgages for single-family housing within specific timeframes set by the Federal Housing Finance Agency Director. The Act "Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011" requires Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to lower interest rates on qualified mortgages for single-family housing. The Director shall exempt certain qualified mortgages from interest rate reduction programs. Under the Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are required to lower interest rates on qualified mortgages for single-family housing. The program allows for fixed-rate mortgages with lower interest rates and adjustable-rate mortgages with capped interest rates. Enterprises must provide an option to opt-out of the program. The Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011 mandates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce interest rates on qualified mortgages for single-family housing. Enterprises must notify mortgagors of proposed rate reductions and offer an opt-out option. The Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011 requires Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to lower interest rates on qualified mortgages for single-family homes. The program allows for rate reductions without treating the modified mortgage as a new one. Definitions for terms like "Director" and "qualified mortgage" are provided in the legislation. The Affordable Mortgage for Homeowners Act of 2011 mandates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to reduce interest rates on eligible mortgages for one- to four-family dwellings occupied by the homeowner. The mortgages must be owned or guaranteed by the Federal National Mortgage Association or the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and originated before the enactment of the Act. The Director is required to issue regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment to implement the program.
